UAE to Enforce Emiratisation Targets Starting July 1, 2025
From July 1, 2025, the UAE will begin inspecting private companies with 50+ employees to assess compliance with Emiratisation quotas and related requirements like social security registration, requiring a 1% increase in skilled Emirati hires by June 30, 2025, as part of the annual 2% goal toward reaching 10% Emiratisation by the end of 2026, with non-compliant companies incurring monthly fines and compliant ones eligible for incentives including up to 80% discounts on fees and preferential government procurement treatment.

UAE’s New Media Law for Influencers
Effective May 29, 2024, Federal Media Law No. 55 of 2023 requires influencers and content creators to hold a Business Licence (AED 5,000–15,000) and a Media Licence (AED 1,000 annually), mandates compliance with 20 content standards, and empowers the UAE Media Council to monitor and act on violations, with penalties reaching up to AED 1 million depending on offense severity and frequency.

UAE to Enforce Full Ban on Single – Use plastics by 2026
The UAE has announced a nationwide ban on the import, production, and trade of all single-use plastic products effective January 1, 2026, following the 2024 plastic bag ban and aligning with its step-by-step sustainability strategy and global environmental initiatives such as the Clean Rivers program and the UAE’s Circular Economy Policy.

UAE New Regulations affecting Tax Treatment
Under Federal Decree-Law No. 47/2022, a Cabinet Decision issued on May 24, 2025 regulates the tax treatment of unincorporated partnerships from tax periods on or after June 1, 2023, allowing them to opt for business taxation with FTA approval, removing prior notification requirements, and aiming to improve compliance and transparency in the UAE corporate tax regime.

DMCC Introduces New Corporate Licenses
The Dubai Multi Commodities Centre (DMCC) has launched two new licenses: the Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV) Licence, which supports passive investment structures with reduced administrative requirements, and the Holding Company Licence, which facilitates simplified ownership, regional oversight, and consolidated management of subsidiaries and assets.

ADGM Studies New Consumer Protection Regulations
In May 2025, ADGM’s Registration Authority issued draft Consumer Protection Regulations 2025 mandating clear product labeling, banning restrictive clauses, requiring ad pre-approval, enforcing refund and service guarantees, and enabling consumers to file claims directly with the ADGM Court, with enforcement including investigations, recalls, and fines.

Federal Tax Authority Announces Waiver Scheme for Corporate Tax Late Registration Penalties – 01 May 2025
The UAE Federal Tax Authority announced a waiver scheme for administrative penalties <https://onechalhoub.connexionsnow.com/mtracking/linkref.php?link1id=1468&user=10620>  related to late corporate tax registration, allowing businesses to receive a penalty waiver or refund if they file their first corporate tax return or annual declaration within seven months after the end of their first tax period or financial year, to support transition and voluntary compliance.

UAE Federal Tax Authority has issued new guides and clarifications in relation to Corporate Tax and Value Added Tax
The FTA issued a guide on interest deduction limitations (April 15, 2025), a Family Foundations tax transparency guide (May 28, 2025), and VAT clarifications including VATP040 on telecom, zero-rating, virtual assets, and VATP043 (May 1, 2025) expanding reverse charge on jewellery where the precious component is dominant and the recipient is VAT-registered with proper declaration.

UAE Ministry of Finance has issued new Ministerial Decisions in relation to Corporate Tax, Pillar Two and E-invoicing
Ministerial Decision No. 84 of 2025 requires all tax groups to prepare audited special purpose financial statements from January 1, 2025; Ministerial Decision No. 88 (April 16, 2025) adopts OECD GloBE Rules aligning the UAE’s DMTT with Pillar Two; and Ministerial Decision No. 64 (March 20, 2025) sets eligibility and accreditation standards for service providers under the UAE’s Electronic Invoicing System launching in Q2 2026.

New Commercial Registry and Trade Names Systems Implemented
Effective April 3, 2025, the Ministry of Commerce launched a unified national registry (UNR) to streamline business operations. Key features include mandatory annual electronic confirmation of data (with non-compliance leading to account block or closure), linking bank accounts to business entities, enhanced protection for trade names, and a prohibition on registering similar names across different activities.

AI Latest Legislative Developments
The CST proposed an AI Draft Law to position Saudi Arabia as a global AI hub. It promotes peaceful AI development by local and foreign entities, enables bilateral agreements for AI hub oversight, and mandates compliance with both local and international laws.

KSA Launches Regulatory Framework for the Ministry of Finance
A new regulatory framework aims to enhance transparency, accountability, and decision-making within the Ministry of Finance, streamline intergovernmental interactions, and align financial management with Vision 2030 goals.

KSA Issues New Credit Card Rules
Effective within 30–90 days from June 19, 2025, SAMA’s new regulations include mandatory SMS alerts for transactions and fee changes, free e-wallet top-ups, capped cash withdrawal and international transaction fees, flexible fund usage, a 25-day grace period for repayments, and standardized disclosure templates.

ZATCA Issues Guideline on Amended VAT Implementing Regulations – 22 April 2025
New VAT rules require group members to be KSA-resident entities with at least 50% common ownership. Entities in special economic zones are mostly excluded. One representative handles compliance; all members share liability. Definitions of services and rules on deemed supplies have been updated, with most changes effective immediately and some from January 1, 2026.

Saudi Arabia Increases Undeveloped Land Tax from 2.5% to Up to 10% of Property Value – 01 May 2025
The revised White Land Tax Law increases tax rates up to 10%, expands scope to include long-vacant buildings, and sets a 5,000 sqm minimum for taxable land in urban areas. Implementation will be phased, starting with larger parcels. Executive regulations are expected within 90 days.

Nationalisation Legislative Developments
Effective April 17, 2025, the Nationalisation Law mandates private sector employers to recruit and train Qatari nationals, use a standard employment contract registered with the Ministry of Labour, and submit biannual reports on Qatari employment. Non-compliance may result in penalties such as visa blocks, trade license suspensions, and imprisonment for fraudulent practices.

Qatar Amends Anti-Money Laundering Law
The Cabinet approved draft amendments to Qatar’s AML Law (Law No. 20/2019) and its executive regulations to align with international standards. The changes aim to strengthen the National Anti-Money Laundering and Terrorism Financing Committee’s role in detection, prevention, and international cooperation. Final approval is pending Shura Council review.

Qatar Introduces a Penalty Waiver and Extends Filing Deadline – 12 March 2025
From March 1, 2025, for six months, taxpayers can benefit from a 100% penalty waiver if they register, file, and pay dues while maintaining compliance through 2028. Additionally, the 2024 fiscal year filing deadline is extended to August 31, 2025, except for oil and gas sector companies.

Qatar Publishes Global Minimum Tax Rules – 27 March 2025
Qatar enacted Law No. (22) of 2024, introducing local Global Minimum Tax Rules through an Income Inclusion Rule (IIR) and Domestic Minimum Top-up Tax (DMTT) applicable to multinational groups. These rules apply across all Qatari jurisdictions, including QFC, QFZA, QSTP, and QMC.

Kuwait implements New Bankruptcy and Anti-Corruption Measures
As of April 26, 2025, amendments to Kuwait’s Bankruptcy Law allow for the arrest and imprisonment of debtors avoiding repayment. Enforcement is strengthened through mandatory financial disclosures and credit reporting. Amendments to the Anti-Corruption Law establish a Public Authority for Anti-Corruption, expand the definition of corruption, and require electronic financial disclosures. Additionally, Ministerial Decision No. 194/2025 mandates that payments for official documents be made via bank transfers or certified checks to curb money laundering and increase transparency.

Kuwait Toughens Stance on AML Procedures 

On May 22, 2025, Kuwait’s Central Bank adopted new AML mechanisms aligned with Article 15 of Law No. 106/2013. Key features include stronger, proportionate penalties; public disclosure of penalties; mandatory use of advanced detection systems by financial institutions; and automatic alerts to the Financial Investigation Unit for suspicious account activity.

Kuwait Amends Ultimate Beneficial Ownership Requirements - 10 March 2025
Ministerial Decision No. 16 of 2025 revises Kuwait’s UBO framework, expanding exemptions, increasing disclosure requirements (including senior management details), and introducing stricter enforcement through fines and potential company delisting. The changes aim to enhance corporate transparency and regulatory oversight.

Proposal to Extend Maternity Leave
Bahrain’s National Assembly is reviewing a proposal to increase public sector maternity leave to 70 days, aligning with UN Sustainable Development Goal 5 on gender equality. The proposal may impact work schedules, require temporary staff, and increase government spending.

Labor Law Amendment
An amendment to Labor Law No. 36/2012, approved on April 30, 2025, mandates full compensation for employees terminated for economic reasons unless the Labour Ministry is notified 60 days in advance. Employers must also submit audited financial records for the past three years and meet strict criteria, such as business closure or production changes.

New Regulations on Returned Cheques
Proposed amendments to Bahrain’s Commercial Law aim to simplify cheque processing and strengthen rights of beneficiaries. Key features include mandatory partial payments on bounced cheques, re-submission rights, and limits on banks’ liability. Issuing blank cheques as credit or guarantees will be penalized with fines up to BHD 10,000.

Bahrain announces an intention to issue a broad-based Corporate Income Tax regime 

Bahrain’s 2025/2026 budget includes an 8-point action plan with key tax measures: introduction of a broad-based corporate income tax, no VAT rate increase, expansion of excise tax scope, and introduction of carbon emission taxes.

National Bureau for Revenue releases Domestic Minimum Top-Up Tax (DMTT) Administrative Guide – May 2025 

The NBR has recently published a DMTT Administrative Guide <https://onechalhoub.connexionsnow.com/mtracking/linkref.php?link1id=1469&user=10620>  which sets out the general principles relating to various administrative aspects of the DMTT implementation in Bahrain.

Oman Launches Electronic Transactions
Royal Decree No. 39/2025 enacts a new Electronic Transactions Law (ETL), transferring regulatory oversight to the Ministry of Transport, Communications, and Information Technology. The law establishes legal trust in digital transactions, including signatures and identity systems, and mandates compliance with cryptographic and security tools. Non-compliance can lead to fines up to OMR 50,000 and imprisonment of up to 5 years.

Oman Introduces Personal Income Tax Law Effective 2028 

Under Royal Decree No. 56/2025, Oman will implement a 5% personal income tax starting in 2028 on individuals earning over OMR 42,000 annually, exempting most citizens. This move supports Vision 2040 by diversifying income sources and reducing oil reliance, aiming to raise non-oil GDP contribution to 15% by 2030 and 18% by 2040.

The Executive Regulations are to be issued within a year. The Tax Authority will also publish guidance materials to support compliance.
